head.hi:
Interesting Correspondance with M. Alex. de Hum-
boldt.

div.p:
—The Ocean Steam Navigation Company of
this city having determined to call the third and fourth
steamers of their line the Franklin and the Humboldt,
authorized their President, Mr. Sand, to inform M.
de Humboldt of their intention, and beg his sanction
to giving his name to one of their ships. The letter
was forwarded to Berlin through the medium of the
Prussian Minister at Washington, M. de Gerolt, and
by the last arrival, the President of the Company
was favored with M. de Humboldt’s reply, through
the medium of Mr. Donelson, our Minister at Ber-
lin.

We have the pleasure of laying before our readers
a translation of this letter, containing so pleasing an
expression of the generous sentiments of one of the
greatest spirits of the age.

p.hi:
To C. H. Sand, Esq., President of the Ocean Steam
Nav. Co., New York:

div.p:
Mr. President: Through the medium of my old
Friend, Mr. de Gerolt, our Minister in the U. States,
I have to day—while occupied with the preparations
for a journey to Paris—received the friendly letter,
dated 21st August, with which you have been pleased
to honor me. It imformsinforms me that a favor has
just been conferred on me, of which I could
not believe myself worthy, of associating my
my my
name with that of a great citizen, who from my
earliest youth, has been the object of my liveliest
admiration. I venture to request you, sir, to present
the homage of my respectful acknowledgements to
the gentlemen directors of the Ocean Steam Navi-
gation Co., who, on the flattering motion of Mr.
Stephens, have determined that the fourth ship of
their line of mail steamers between New York and
Bremen shall bear my name.

In rendering you, Mr. President, the interpreter of
my sentiments, you will be pleased to accept the ex-
pression of my gratitude due to your kind co-opera-
tion, and the delicacy of your proceedings. Devo-
ted as I am, by my travels and labors to the noble
destinies of the new continent, and taking the most
lively interest in the most direct and closest com-
mercial intercourse between the United States and
my country, I put the highest value on the honor
which you confer upon me, in the decline of a life
which has had no other merit than that of a coura-
geous perseverance in the love of afor the good and free-
dom of opinion.

closer.salute:
I have the honor to remain,
With the highest consideration,
Sir, your ob’t humble servant.
ALEX. DE HUMBOLDT.
